text: big thank you to Squarespace for
sponsoring this video in some of my
recent videos you've seen me shoot a lot
of photos as part of a project I'm
making in Jersey and I do get a lot of
technical questions related to nighttime
photography and specifically how to do
it on film because obviously when you
can't see your photos it's a lot more
intimidating to go out and shoot in new
lighting conditions like nighttime but
there's a couple things that you can do
that really will make it so much easier
and give you the confidence to make some
good nighttime photos this week I'm
gonna share some of my tips and also
show you some more photos that I shot in
Wildwood New Jersey at night because I
didn't get to showcase all of those in
the original video that I put out from
there I have made a video in the past
about night photography on film
specifically so if you haven't seen that
one maybe go check it out first without
further ado the first thing that you
need to do is obviously have a secure
tripod and a cable release to eliminate
any camera shake that might happen in
your camera when you do any kind of
exposure that's longer than a sixtieth
of a second with a film camera you're
generally gonna need a tripod because
even the smallest shake in the camera
will show up very significantly on a
photo especially when you start zooming
in so having a nice tripod and a cable
release just make sure that you get a
really steady shot I have this steel
tripod by Promaster which works really
nicely it is slightly heavier and more
expensive but because I shoot mainly on
an RZ 67 which is a heavier film camera
it does make sense to own this the next
thing might seem slightly obvious but
this wasn't something I knew before
somebody told me and that's to shoot on
color film because color film just has
naturally much more dynamic range than
black and white film nighttime scenes
are generally super contrast II because
you're gonna be photographing a very
dark sky or subject against some kind of
street lighting or some window lighting
and that's generally a massive
contrast it might not seem like a
massive contrast to our eyes but to our
camera that really is a lot or just
using color film is a really nice trick
because it gives you the most dynamic
range and hopefully if you do things
right you're gonna be able to capture
that really dark sky but also have a
decent exposure on some of the bright
light sources in the photo the next part
which is arguably the most difficult out
of all of this is figuring out the
exposure that you want to shoot at when
you first start out this can be pretty
intimidating but after you do enough
night photography it becomes second
nature just like shooting at daytime
does in the footage from wild wood you
can see me using my handheld sekonic
light meter the model name of this thing
is the L 308 X - you and there's a
couple different ways that you can meet
her a night scene I usually do a couple
different things and try to take an
average reading now the first thing that
you need to do is because it's so dark
at night you can actually read the light
sources so we're gonna be sliding the
dome away from the sensor and using the
light meter on what's called reflective
metering this is basically where you
point the light meter at the scene that
you're photographing and it's gonna take
a reading and tell you what to shoot
your photo at now generally I'll point
my light meter somewhere in a neutral
gray area that I want the photo to be
exposed for this usually is somewhere
between the light source and the darkest
part of the photo just so I get an
average reading these light meters have
a very wide pickup range so it's gonna
be an overall reading here if you want
to expose for the shadows make sure that
you point your light meter in the
direction of the darker area of the
photo now this really is something that
you have to just go out and do I can sit
here and explain it all day but the
easiest way to learn this is to just go
out with a camera and some film an
experiment figuring out how your process
works best I generally would recommend a
light meter for night photography
because phones are great for daytime but
for these more sensitive low-light
situations a light meter is generally
going to be much more accurate my phone
meter usually doesn't get anything right
a fourth to the second now in Wildwood
when I'm shooting photos like this I'll
always be shooting at f/8 11 or 16
because I want the whole team in focus
and that generally means that my
exposures are gonna be pretty long they
tend to go anywhere from 4 seconds all
the way up to 2 minutes but on average I
would say that I'm shooting most things
at f/8 at 8 seconds there's a couple
ways that I calculate this and the first
step is obviously metering the scene
like I showed you previously but then
also taking into account my next tip
which is reciprocity failure this is
kind of a tough concept to wrap your
head around but I promise it gets easier
with more practice reciprocity failure
is basically the idea that as you expose
the film it loses sensitivity over time
that it's being exposed there's a really
simple graph that sums this up very
nicely online I had this graph saved on
my phone when I started shooting film
and I recommend you do the same this is
specifically for portrait films and it
tells you how much to overexpose the
film by at a given shutter speed so
generally if you're getting a light
meter reading for example that says 8
seconds I end up shooting at 15 seconds
because it needs a full stop of
overexposure I have one more tip for you
but for now enjoy some more night photos
from Wildwood
[Music]
the last thing that's arguably one of
the most important parts of this whole
knife photography thing is just looking
for scenes that aren't too contrasting
this is something I do a lot of the
times so what I generally do is look for
nice spots that have ambient light like
moonlight or street lights or lights
coming from a parking lot something of
that nature and overall I just look for
scenes that aren't too contrasty because
I know that the film isn't gonna be able
to render those one of the best times to
shoot night photos is right after sunset
this is called the blue hour and towards
the end of the blue hour you got enough
ambient light that it lights up the
whole scene but also still looks like
nighttime because it is technically dark
enough one of my favorite photos that
I've talked about recently for this New
Jersey project was taken exactly like
this towards the end of blue hour and I
think that worked out really well
experiment have fun with it and finally
I want to thank Squarespace for
sponsoring this video
